snippet: James Mitchell, a former Air Force trainer, and a partner designed, led and directed the interrogations and became the prime advocates for what is now widely considered to have been torture.
abstract: Former CIA officials involved in interrogation program of suspected terrorists after 9/11 attacks say desperation was behind speed with which agency turned to contractors James Mitchell and Bruce Jensen to direct interrogations; scathing Senate Intelligence Committee report says interrogation techniques amounted to torture.

byline.original: By JAMES RISEN and MATT APUZZO
byline.contributor: Marilyn Garateix contributed reporting from Land O’ Lakes, Fla., and Bill Loftus from Spokane, Wash.

lead_paragraph: James Mitchell, a former Air Force trainer, and a partner designed, led and directed the interrogations and became the prime advocates for what is now widely considered to have been torture.

headline.main: C.I.A., on Path to Torture, Chose Haste Over Analysis
headline.print_headline: C.I.A., on Path to Torture, Chose Haste Over Analysis
